content:
Hi,

The Rust cookbook recommends chrono for all types of datetime ops: https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-cookbook/datetime.html, and chrono is the de-facto crate for this.

However, it seems that the crate is unmaintained: there are multiple issues and PRs un-handled and no code changes in the past 8 months or so.
Given the ubiquitous importance of first class support for datetimes, should we address this?
Have you tried reaching out to the maintainers? What is your proposal? That is, who do you mean by "we" in your question?
I think the underlying time crate that crono wraps, is now maintained and does most of what crono used to do. But I could be wrong.

Jorge Leitao said:

...The Rust cookbook recommends chrono for all types of datetime ops: https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-cookbook/datetime.html, and chrono is the de-facto crate for this.

However, it seems that the crate is unmaintained...

Does the cookbook have any specific examples that would be invalidated by bugs that have been brought up?

Thanks for the feedback. @Tim McNamara , I have not - I usually evaluate these from the issue tracker alone; we: myself and anyone that depends on chrono that sees this as an issue (if anyone): I was unaware of time and thus was a bit worried that there would not be continuity / maintenance on the time handling front. With a second crate this is not so problematic imo. @Jubilee , AFAIK no: my only point with the cookbook reference was to mention chrono widely acceptance within Rust.
